content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Seems nice and clear.
Works for both fastest and shortest

I found it hard because I assumed I need to convert decimal to roman then count the triplets. I am 100% sure majority of the clashers would assume this after reading the statement. 

Following statement makes the assumption stronger.

"For more information on how Roman numerals work, see: https://www.britannica.com/topic/Roman-numeral"

However I did not understand the 3-8 trick. 36 is 2 digit number but has 1 triplet. Can you explain @thobbes?
It would be more interesting if the output were only the roman numbers .

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This rewards payers, that spent time thinking of a solution before just looking it up online.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: (In my opinion) the 3-8 trick is not a trick, it is the intended solution, but even if it is not, I find it a good contribution.

A large part of this is being able to convert a number to roman numerals.
Even if I know already how roman numerals work, it is significantly faster to search for "{language} code to convert to roman numerals" than it is to write my own conversion. 
IMO, clashes which give this type of advantage to those who copy/paste code from elsewhere are badly-designed.

I see where you're coming from and I thought about it.

But if you look closely, the roman number part is mostly a red herring: only 3 and 8 digits make triplets, so once you notice this you can take that shortcut and avoid having to convert altogether. That is what I do in my solution.

In the end I feel that those who go and search for conversion algorithms to copypaste end up having a disadvantage rather than an advantage.

If you and others feel differently though, maybe I could change it to shortest only instead of fastest, so copypasters' disadvantage would be definitive.

@codybumba sorry for the delay. "3 and 8 digits" means "the digits '3' and '8'". In Roman numbering 3s and 8s are represented with triplets, all the other numbers are not. That is why 36 has one (XXXVI). 38 would have two (XXXVIII), 338 would have three (CCCXXXVIII), 883 would have three (DCCCLXXXIII), 208 would have one (CCVIII), etc.

I understand your assumption, but as @shuhu pointed out it's part of the "ruse" on the player: the idea is to reward thinking with your brain rather than your fingers.

Thanks for the explanation.

But I still think it is hard for CoC since I doubt many people know about this trick!

I have to admit, I didn't spot the "3s and 8s" trick.

Faced with a "converted to a Roman numeral" statement, under the time pressure of a CoC, I suspect that the vast majority of people will think "I need a function to convert to roman numerals", rather than "how can I avoid having to write a conversion to roman numerals?".

I'm not sure I like this, but I'm now less concerned about the possibility of someone copy/pasting (unnecessary) conversion code.
